data.title: A British Town Changed Its Name Because of Comedian Sacha Baron Cohen
data.meta_description: In this week's Maphead, Ken Jennings explores the British town that changed its name to distance itself from a fictional character.
data.text:
Every time a town or city changes its name, thousands of residents have to be convinced to undergo the inconvenience…so there's usually a story to tell. Some towns are cashing in, like Jim Thorpe, Pennsylvania and Truth or Consequences, New Mexico. Others are running away from a problematic past (to wit: Sexmoan in the Philippines). The most recent addition to the trend is the quiet English town of Staines, which got tired of being a comedy punch line.

Ali G was British television's favorite gangsta.

British comedian Sacha Baron Cohen made it big in America as a title-confused Kazakh in the 2006 movie Borat, but in the U.K. he was already well-known for playing a different character: Ali G, the fictional host of Da Ali G Show. In his trademark patois, half hip-hop and half Jamaican, Ali G would brag about coming up "in da heart of da Staines ghetto" and leading a local street gang, "Da West Staines Massive."

Staines was better known for its linoleum than its rap scene.

The joke, which a British viewer would have understood instantly, was that Ali G wasn't "hard" at all, he was Alistair Lester Graham, a middle-class white boy playing at thug life. Far from being an urban ghetto, Staines is a suburban market town near Heathrow Airport, best known over the years for its linoleum factory. It has a lovely Victorian town hall and a market street of charming Georgian shophouses. The town is old; its manor was mentioned in the 11th-century Domesday Book, and Sir Thomas More was tried there in 1535.

Can a comedy bit lower property values?

Some residents of Staines didn't appreciate their historically reputable town being besmirched in comedy sketches. They evidently didn't get the point of the joke: Sasha Baron Cohen used Staines as Ali G's hometown precisely because of its amiable respectability. But no matter! A local business forum thought that Baron Cohen's joke was lowering property values. "There’s no doubt Ali G put Staines on the map—but for all the wrong reasons," said the forum chairman. "He put the stain in Staines."

Staines, upon Thames, is now Staines-upon-Thames.

In 2012, the business forum convinced the borough council to make the switch, and at 2 p.m. on May 20, the town celebrated with a maypole dance and regatta as the name was officially changed. The local football club complained loudly that the new name was "pretentious"—but to no avail. Staines is now Staines-upon-Thames. I wonder if Kazakhstan has considered a name change as well, to get rid of the Borat-inflicted stains upon its reputation.
